title: Luck, skill, or prayer? Did the Broncos deserve to make the playoffs in 2011?
text:
Tebowing and Tebowmania took the NFL world by storm in 2011 when the Denver Broncos somehow snuck into the playoffs by winning their division with an 8-8 record. In case you don’t remember, Tebowing is when Tim Tebow would drop to one knee on the field, his head bowed meeting his fist and pray. 
It always seemed like the Broncos were a prayer away from victory. Maybe, that’s because in most cases they were. 13 of their 18 games they either won or lost by less than a touchdown, if we include the playoff game against the 12-4 Pittsburgh Steelers and the New England Patriots. That must have been a stressful season for a Broncos fan. But, were all these narrowly decided games luck, skill, or the source of a higher power? 
The Broncos made the playoffs because they won their division. Hence why they were able to play a home playoff game against the Steelers. Looking at the other eight teams that finished 8-8 or 9-7 but did not make the playoffs, how did Denver match up? We’ll also look at the Steelers who the Broncos beat in the first round of the playoffs. Just to have a baseline of what a playoff team’s stats look like. 
Granted the Broncos are in the AFC so an NFC team who finished 8-8 is not eligible to make the playoffs in the AFC. But, what’s the harm in looking? 
Surely a division winner should get to be in the playoffs, but did they deserve it? To measure how good a team is we can look at their offense and defense as a whole. One way to do this is with the turnover margin. 


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)

stats <- read_csv("2011BroncosStatSheet.csv")

broncos <- stats |> filter(Team == "Denver Broncos")
steelers <- stats |> filter(Team== "Pittsburgh Steelers")

eightsbar <- stats |>
  filter(Record == "8-8" | Record == "9-7") |>
  filter(Playoffs == "N")|>
  group_by(Team)

tables <- bind_rows(broncos, steelers, eightsbar)

table <- tables |>
  mutate(
    turnovermargin = Takeaways - TO
  )

table |> 
  select(Team, TO, Takeaways, turnovermargin)|>
  arrange(desc(turnovermargin)) |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TO = "Turnovers",
    Takeaways = "Takeaways",
    turnovermargin = "Turnover Margin",
    theme_minimal()
  )|>
tab_header(
    title = "Total turnovers, total takeaways, and turnover margin",
    subtitle = "Did the Broncos have the worst turnover margin?"
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color="black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|> 
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Erik Cumley  |  **Source:** Sports Football Reference")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=15)
     )
   ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#FB4F14"),
      cell_text(color = "navy")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Denver Broncos")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "black"),
      cell_text(color = "gold")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Pittsburgh Steelers")
  )

The Broncos finished with the fourth worst turnover margin of the teams. But, wait they’re above the Steelers! That’s a playoff team, thus the Broncos deserved to make the playoffs right? Well not quite, that season the Steelers finished with the No. 1 defense in the NFL. If your defense is ranked No. 1 in the entire NFL it’s okay that your turnover margin isn’t the greatest. 
The other two teams the Broncos are ahead of were two NFC teams. Of the AFC teams the Broncos had the worst turnover margin, and it’s not very close. Two of the teams ahead of the Broncos are even in their division. At the time the San Diego Chargers and Oakland Raiders both had much better turnover margins than Denver. 
Turnovers and takeaways may influence the game but what wins games? Points! Scoring wins games. Score more than your opponent and you win regardless of turnovers, penalties, rushing yards, passing yards, etc. Maybe the Broncos just had ridiculous points for and points against.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

stats <- read_csv("2011BroncosStatSheet.csv")

broncos <- stats |> filter(Team == "Denver Broncos")
steelers <- stats |> filter(Team== "Pittsburgh Steelers")

eights <- stats |>
  filter(Record == "8-8" | Record == "9-7") |>
  filter(Playoffs == "N")|>
  group_by(Team)

eightsdumb <- bind_rows(broncos, steelers, eights)

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=eightsdumb, 
    aes(y=reorder(Team, PtsFor), x=PtsFor, xend=PtsAllowed),
    size = 1.5,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red")+
   labs(
    title="Points for and points against", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>Points For</span> are on the right, that's good. If <span style = 'color:red;'>Points Allowed</span> are on the right, that's bad.",
    x="Points scored", 
    y="",
    caption="Source: Sports Football Reference | By: Erik Cumley"
    )+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Well that’s even worse than the turnover margin. The green dots represent how many points for the team while the red dots represent how many points went against the team. In total Denver finished with 309 total points and 390 points were scored against them. Not only did they get scored on the second most of the other teams, they also finished last in points for! And the No. 1 defense Steelers just didn’t allow anyone to score. Meanwhile, the Chargers sit atop with 406 points for and 377 points against. It’s clear the efficiency of scoring was not there.


Code
library(tidyverse)

stats <- read_csv("2011BroncosStatSheet.csv")

eightsbar <- stats |>
  filter(Record == "8-8" | Record == "9-7") |>
  filter(Playoffs == "N")|>
  group_by(Team)

broncos <- stats |> filter(Team == "Denver Broncos")
steelers <- stats |> filter(Team== "Pittsburgh Steelers")

bar <- bind_rows(eightsbar, broncos, steelers)

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = bar, aes(x=reorder(Team, PctEndScore), weight=PctEndScore), fill="lightgray")+
  geom_bar(data=broncos, aes(x=Team, weight=PctEndScore), fill="#FB4F14")+
  geom_bar(data = steelers, aes(x=Team, weight=PctEndScore), fill = "#FFB612")+
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="",
    y="Percentage each drive end in score",
    title = "Percentage each offensive drive to end in points",
    subtitle = "The Broncos had the lowest percentage to score on each offensive possession",
    caption="Source: Sports Football Reference | By: Erik Cumley"
  )+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









A whopping 24.5% chance to finish their offensive drives with points. Not touchdowns, just getting points on the board. Each time the Broncos had an offensive possession they had a less than 25% chance of scoring points. Of the other AFC teams all but the Jets had over a 30% chance to score, the Jets sit at 29.6%. Once again the Chargers sit atop with 41.3%. 
How did the 8-8 Broncos not just make the playoffs but defeat a far superior opponent in the Steelers. Denver found its miracle in Tim Tebow who swept the nation. One of the wildest roller coaster seasons would never make a return as the next season Tebow was traded to the New York Jets for a fourth and sixth round pick. 
Looking back on the season it very well could have been the most stressful season in Broncos history. Despite the inefficient offense and the atrocious defense somehow they made the playoffs. With a lot of luck, some skill, and a dash of prayer the Denver Broncos got the job done.
